case_name: M/s. Gandhara Transport Co. Ltd. v. Manohar Singh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 200 of 1962 was filed in the Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated March 15, 1960 of Punjab High Court in Civil Writ No. 315 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 15, 1960, of the Punjab High Court, Chandigarh, in Civil Writ No. 315 of 1960.

facts.text: On October 23, 1956, Regional Transport Authority Patiala granted permit to Manohar Singh for Bhatinda-Khera via Bajekhanna-Jaitu-Kot-Kapura route, 55 miles long.

anchor.surface_text: By order dated October 23, 1956, the Regional Transport Authority, Patiala, granted a permit to one Manohar Singh for plying a stage carriage on the Bhatinda Khera  Via Bajekhanna

facts.text: The route overlapped 35 miles of Bhatinda-Kot-Kapura-Faridkot route for which appellants M/s Gandhara Transport Co. Ltd. held permits.

facts.text: On April 16, 1958, RTA issued notice inviting objections for renewal of permit to Manohar Singh for 3 years on regular basis.

anchor.surface_text: Manohar Singh applied to the Regional Transport Authority for renewal of the permit. The Regional Transport Authority issued on April16, 1958, a numberice inviting objections regarding,

facts.text: RTA posted objections for hearing on July 30, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: and others filed objections to the renewal of the permits for three years on regular basis. The regional Transport Authority posted the objections for hearing on July 30, 1958.

facts.text: On July 29, 1958, Punjab HC rejected appellants' application for interim stay.

anchor.surface_text: In the mean time the appellants applied to the High Court of Punjab for an interim order directing the Regional Transport Authority to stay pronouncement of the order on the application

facts.text: On August 1, 1958, RTA granted regular permit for three years to Manohar Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The Regional Transport Authority declined to postpone announcement of its orders and on August 1, 1958, directed that a regular permit for three years be granted to Manohar Singh

facts.text: On August 7, 1958, Punjab HC dismissed appellants' writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: Section 62 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939, empowers the Regional Transport Authority to grant without following the procedure laid down in s. 57 of the Act and subject to such conditions as it thinks fit to impose, permits to be effective for a limited Period  not in any case exceeding four months  authorising the use of a transport vehicle- a  for the conveyance of passengers on special occasions such as to and from fairs and religious gatherings, or  b  for the purpose of a seasonal business, or  c  to meet a particular need, or  d  pending decision of an application for the renewal of a permit.

concepts.interpretation: Empowers grant of temporary permits without s.57 procedure for limited period and specific temporary needs; amended by Act 100 of 1956 with restrictions on grant during pendency of new or renewal applications

anchor.surface_text: After the expiry of the period of the temporary permit in his favour, Manohar Singh applied not for a regular permit under s. 57, but for renewal of a temporary permit. The Act, however, does not contemplate renewal of temporary permits only regular permits may be renewed under s. 58 of the Act.

concepts.interpretation: Statutory interpretation: no provision for renewing temporary permits into regular; must apply afresh under s.57

issues.text: Whether the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939 contemplates renewal of temporary permits granted under Section 62 into regular permits under Section 57 or Section 58?

anchor.surface_text: After the expiry of the period of the temporary permit in his favour, Manohar Singh applied not for a regular permit under s. 57, but for renewal of a temporary permit. The Act, however, does not contemplate renewal of temporary permits only regular permits may be renewed under s. 58 of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the Regional Transport Authority followed the proper procedure under Section 57, including inviting fresh applications from the public, before granting a regular permit for the first time on the route?

anchor.surface_text: The Regional Transport Authority invited objections to the application of Manohar Singh for renewal of the permit for a period of three years on regular basis without indicating that Manohar Singh was the holder of a temporary permit. As we have already observed there were on the route specified in the application no regular permits issued under s. 57 and all the permits which were issued by the Authority were temporary permits under s.62. The Regional Transport Authority had, therefore for the first time to issue regular permits under s.57 of the Act and that authority might well have, before considering applications submitted by holders of temporary permits, invited applications from persons who were interested in applying for permits for the route in question.

issues.text: Whether the Regional Transport Authority considered the matters specified in clauses (a) to (f) of Section 47 of the Motor Vehicles Act before granting the stage carriage permit?

anchor.surface_text: In considering an application for a permit for a stage carriage normally the Regional Transport Authority has to consider matters set out in clauses  a  to  f  of s. 47 such as the interest of the public generally, the advantages to the public of the service to be provided, including the saving of time likely to be effected thereby, adequacy of other passenger transport services

issues.text: Whether the proceedings of the Regional Transport Authority were vitiated on account of grave errors of procedure, rendering the grant of permit unlawful?

anchor.surface_text: But the Regional Transport Authority committed an error at the threshold of his proceeding it entertained an application which is not contemplated by any provision of the Act, invited objections thereto in terms which were somewhat misleading, thereby preventing other applicants from coming forward to apply, and failed to apply its mind to matters which had to he considered under s. 47 of the Motor Vehicles Act. Therefore by entertaining an application for renewal of a temporary permit and inviting objections against such renewal the Regional Transport Authority entertained an application which was not in law maintainable, and by inviting objections to the application as one for renewal for three years on regular basis in substance misled the parties desiring to enter into competition into desisting from sub- mitting their applications. Its proceedings were, therefore, in our judgment, vitiated on account of grave errors of procedure.

issues.text: Whether the question of validity of the Regional Transport Authority's order granting the permit has become academic since the permit period has expired?
Whether the Act contains provision for renewal of a temporary permit into a regular permit, and whether the Regional Transport Authority failed to invite public applications for the route?

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then moved the High Court of Punjab by a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution for quashing the order of the Secretary, Transport Department, on the pleas, inter alia, that the order passed by the Secretary was illegal because it ignored the effect of the temporary permit which was the basis on which the permanent permit was granted to Manohar Singh, that the authority had failed to notice that the Regional Transport Authority had not invited applications from the public for granting permit for the route and had merely notified the application for renewal of the permit of the third respondent and that the Act contained no provision for renewal of a temporary permit into a regular permit.

holdings.text: The Act does not contemplate renewal of temporary permits; only regular permits may be renewed under s. 58 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: After the expiry of the period of the temporary permit in his favour, Manohar Singh applied not for a regular permit under s. 57, but for renewal of a temporary permit. The Act, however, does not contemplate renewal of temporary permits only regular permits may be renewed under s. 58 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sections 57, 58, and 62 distinguish temporary permits (limited duration, no formal procedure) from regular permits (renewable, formal s.57 process); no statutory provision allows converting or renewing temporary into regular.

holdings.text: The Regional Transport Authority had for the first time to issue regular permits under s.57 and should have invited applications from the public before granting.

anchor.surface_text: The Regional Transport Authority invited objections to the application of Manohar Singh for renewal of the permit for a period of three years on regular basis without indicating that Manohar Singh was the holder of a temporary permit. As we have already observed there were on the route specified in the application no regular permits issued under s. 57 and all the permits which were issued by the Authority were temporary permits under s.62. The Regional Transport Authority had, therefore for the first time to issue regular permits under s.57 of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: No prior regular permits existed on route (f18, f22, f24); first issuance requires full s.57 procedure including public notice to allow competition, unlike temporary permits.

holdings.text: The Regional Transport Authority failed to consider matters set out in clauses (a) to (f) of s. 47 before granting the permit.

anchor.surface_text: In considering an application for a permit for a stage carriage normally the Regional Transport Authority has to consider matters set out in clauses (a) to (f) of s. 47 such as the interest of the public generally, the advantages to the public of the service to be provided, including the saving of time likely to be effected thereby, adequacy of other passenger transport services

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.47 mandates consideration of public interest factors (adequacy of services, benefits to localities, road conditions); no evidence RTA applied mind to these in invalid renewal process.

holdings.text: The proceedings of the Regional Transport Authority were vitiated on account of grave errors of procedure, rendering the grant of permit unlawful.

anchor.surface_text: But the Regional Transport Authority committed an error at the threshold of his proceeding it entertained an application which is not contemplated by any provision of the Act, invited objections thereto in terms which were somewhat misleading, thereby preventing other applicants from coming forward to apply, and failed to apply its mind to matters which had to he considered under s. 47 of the Motor Vehicles Act. Therefore by entertaining an application for renewal of a temporary permit and inviting objections against such renewal the Regional Transport Authority entertained an application which was not in law maintainable, and by inviting objections to the application as one for renewal for three years on regular basis in substance misled the parties desiring to enter into competition into desisting from submitting their applications. Its proceedings were, therefore, in our judgment, vitiated on account of grave errors of procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative errors: entertained invalid renewal application (h1), issued misleading notice preventing competition (h2), ignored s.47 factors (h3); violates natural justice and statutory procedure.

holdings.text: It is necessary to declare the true legal position as the matter is not academic; affirming High Court would improperly benefit holder under s.58(2) proviso.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Permit expiry does not moot issue; declaration prevents repetition of errors and avoids unjust preference in future renewals under s.58(2) proviso for invalidly granted permit.

holdings.text: The order of the Regional Transport Authority granting a permit in favour of Manohar Singh was unlawful; High Court order set aside.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly set aside the order passed by the High Court and declare that the order of the Regional Transport Authority granting a permit in favour of Manohar Singh was, for reasons already set out, unlawful.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of above holdings (h1-h4) to facts; procedural vitiations make grant invalid ab initio.

edges.explanation: The holding explicitly states that the Act does not contemplate renewal of temporary permits, directly addressing the core question of the issue.

anchor.surface_text: After the expiry of the period of the temporary permit in his favour, Manohar Singh applied not for a regular permit under s. 57, but for renewal of a temporary permit. The Act, however, does not contemplate renewal of temporary permits only regular permits may be renewed under s. 58 of the Act.

edges.explanation: The holding on no renewal addresses the portion of the issue concerning whether the Act contains provision for renewal of temporary permits.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 addresses issue i2 by stating RTA failed to follow s.57 procedure of inviting applications.

anchor.surface_text: The Regional Transport Authority invited objections to the application of Manohar Singh for renewal of the permit for a period of three years on regular basis without indicating that Manohar Singh was the holder of a temporary permit. As we have already observed there were on the route specified in the application no regular permits issued under s. 57 and all the permits which were issued by the Authority were temporary permits under s.62. The Regional Transport Authority had, therefore for the first time to issue regular permits under s.57 of the Act
We accordingly set aside the order passed by the High Court and declare that the order of the Regional Transport Authority granting a permit in favour of Manohar Singh was, for reasons al

anchor.surface_text: In considering an application for a permit for a stage carriage normally the Regional Transport Authority has to consider matters set out in clauses (a) to (f) of s. 47 such as the interest of the public generally, the advantages to the public of the service to be provided, including the saving of time likely to be effected thereby, adequacy of other passenger transport services
We accordingly set aside the order passed by the High Court and declare that the order of the Regional Transport Authority granting a permit in favour of Manohar Singh was, for reasons al
. Its proceedings were, therefore, in our judgment, vitiated on account of grave errors of procedure. But Mr. Gosain appearing on behalf of the respon

edges.explanation: Holding h4 of vitiation grounds the application of concept c11 describing grave procedural errors.

anchor.surface_text: . Its proceedings were, therefore, in our judgment, vitiated on account of grave errors of procedure. But Mr. Gosain appearing on behalf of the respon

edges.explanation: Holding h4 directly addresses issue i4 by affirming vitiation due to grave procedural errors.

anchor.surface_text: But the Regional Transport Authority committed an error at the threshold of his proceeding it entertained an application which is not contemplated by any provision of the Act, invited objections thereto in terms which were somewhat misleading, thereby preventing other applicants from coming forward to apply, and failed to apply its mind to matters which had to he considered under s. 47 of the Motor Vehicles Act. Therefore by entertaining an application for renewal of a temporary permit and inviting objections against such renewal the Regional Transport Authority entertained an application which was not in law maintainable, and by inviting objections to the application as one for renewal for three years on regular basis in substance misled the parties desiring to enter into competition into desisting from submitting their applications. Its proceedings were, therefore, in our judgment, vitiated on account of grave errors of procedure.
We accordingly set aside the order passed by the High Court and declare that the order of the Regional Transport Authority granting a permit in favour of Manohar Singh was, for reasons al
